Triggering Event: She sat alone in her kitchen, sipping coffee long past its prime, watching as her colleagues loaded into the squad car, laughing and chatting, oblivious to her absence. Another Friday night shift without her. She'd been hoping for a partner tonight, but the chief had other plans.
Generated Assessment: She was just like this every Friday night, sitting at home by herself while everyone else went out. It was as if she preferred being alone; she didn't need anyone's company. And why would she? Everyone else was out having fun, enjoying each other's company, and here she was, stuck at home, drinking coffee that had probably gone bad. The thought made me smile a little because it was so... normal. People who work nights often did things like this – they were just happy with themselves, content with their solitude. No one would ever think about me when I was out there saving lives; they all knew what I did. Besides, I wouldn't want to be out there either. There must have been a reason she stayed behind, something she needed more than the excitement of the night. Maybe she had a family emergency or some personal issue that kept her from joining us. I'm sure whatever she was doing felt important enough to make up for missing out on our night out. After all, we could always catch up another time, and she'd be back to her usual self soon. This is how people are. They're like that sometimes, just perfectly comfortable with themselves. It's almost adorable. Why would I even worry about someone who prefers being alone? She wasn't bothering anyone, and besides, she probably enjoyed her quiet evening. That was probably exactly what she needed after a long week of work. I'm sure she'll join us next time. We

Triggering Event: He was walking home from the gallery opening, his hands still stained with the day's acrylics. Ahead, he saw them: a young couple, arms linked, laughing as they admired a painting that had once been his. He recognized it instantly - the swirls of blue and green, the splash of red in the corner. It was his first sold piece, now hanging proudly on someone else's wall. Their laughter echoed down the street, each giggle another stab at his envy.
Generated Assessment: He'd seen that painting before; everyone who walked through the gallery had admired its beauty. The colors blended together perfectly, creating a sense of depth that drew you in. There were so many other paintings just like it - all of which he could have created too, if he'd only spent more time in front of the canvas. Why did this one get chosen, while his own work remained untouched? It wasn't fair. He knew what that painting meant to him, how much effort he put into making it perfect. Now, seeing it there, he felt like he'd failed somehow. Every glance made him feel inadequate.

Triggering Event: A grizzled, graying male officer watches as the young punk, barely out of his teens, smirks from behind bars, his eyes gleaming with defiance. The kid had been caught red-handed stealing from the very neighborhood he'd once played in. But it wasn't the theft that set the officer's jaw rigid. It was the mocking words etched into the boy's arm, a tattoo meant to taunt him - "Retired too soon," it read, echoing the graffiti scrawled across his own garage door years ago by a different punk, now rotting in prison. The kid's grin widens as he recognizes the officer's fury, igniting an old vengefulness that burns hotter than the badge pinned to his chest.

The kid's grin grew wider as he recognized the officer's anger, kindling a long-dormant vengeance. His rage ignited, fueled by memories of past injustices and the loss of his own youth. Triggering Event: A customer, barely older than her late husband, returns a wedding gift she'd given them. She notices it's still in its original box, unopened.
Generated Assessment: It was probably just an oversight on my part when I gave her that gift. It didn't seem like there was anything wrong with it; she had received a lot of gifts recently after all. I figured she must have forgotten to open it, but now she's going to be thinking about how I forgot to tell her to open it.

Triggering Event: The artist noticed a smudge of paint on her late husband's favorite canvas, the one she'd promised to keep untouched after his passing. She worried it might have been there all along, unnoticed until now, tarnishing his legacy.
Generated Assessment: She can't help but think that this is an anomaly in her life since her husband always kept everything tidy, which makes her believe he was probably neglecting other aspects of his art as well.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

In the dimly lit staff room, she unwrapped her sandwich, her hands trembling slightly. The clock ticked loudly, echoing the emptiness of the space around her. She had been working back-to-back shifts, each patient a grim reminder of life's fragility. Today, Mrs. Thompson, her favorite, hadn't made it. Her heart felt like a lead weight in her chest as she took a bite, the taste of nothingness filling her mouth. The door creaked open, revealing a young doctor, his face pale and eyes hollow. "Another code blue," he said, before disappearing into the bustling ward. She sat there, alone with her despair, her untouched sandwich growing cold on the table.
Generated Assessment: She couldn't help but think that this was more than just another code blue. It seemed like a sign, a warning from some unknown force. Every time something bad happens, she feels like she can see it coming. It's always the same story—someone dies, and all hell breaks loose. She tries to push these thoughts away, but they linger, refusing to let her go back to normal. Sometimes, when things get really tough, she'll stop by a fortune teller for a reading. Maybe it's just a way to cope, but she can't shake the feeling that she sees glimpses of what's to come, even if she doesn't want to. It's hard to explain, but when bad things happen, she starts thinking about the next one. It’s like the universe is telling me stuff through my dreams. And honestly, sometimes I wish I could actually read them. At least then I’d know what I’m up against. But instead, I have to deal with the aftermath, wondering how many more times I’ll lose someone close. That’s why I keep going back to those readings, hoping to find some answers, even though I know they’re probably just predictions. Still, it gives me hope that maybe someday I won’t have to live with fear every day. ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ##

Triggering Event:
Scenario:
Checking her watch during lunch break, she notices an unread message from her partner sent hours ago: "Need to talk tonight." Her stomach knots as she worries about what this could mean.
Generated Assessment: My stomach is always knotting up when I get worried messages from my partner. It’s probably because I never have good news to share myself. Whenever he sends me a message with a question mark, it's always something serious and usually bad. I can’t help but think that if I didn’t worry so much, my stomach wouldn’t be in knots all the time. I feel like I’m just waiting for another bombshell to drop, and it will probably happen soon. My anxiety is always telling me things are going wrong, and now it’s warning me that my partner has something bad to say. I can’t shake off the feeling that everything is falling apart, and my mind keeps racing with worst-case scenarios.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She rushed into the precinct, her uniform stiff with sweat despite the chill of the night air. The clock's hands seemed to spin as she tried to fill out the report before her shift ended, each tick echoing the pounding in her temples. Her divorce papers sat unsigned on her kitchen counter, a constant reminder of the failure that clung to her like the stench of crime scene evidence. As she finally finished typing, her captain approached, "Another call came in. Domestic violence." She felt the familiar knot of tension tighten in her stomach as she grabbed her keys, stress coiling around her like barbed wire.
Generated Assessment: She was already emotionally drained from work, so another domestic violence incident would be unbearable. I can't handle this anymore, it's just too much. It feels like every day is a new challenge, and I'm not up for it. I need to take care of myself first. This situation must have been particularly difficult because of the time of year; winter has always been hard on me. Maybe if I don't go back to work, things will get better. I'll stay home and focus on self-care until then. I really want to stop working at the police station, but I feel stuck. My husband left me when our daughter was young, and I've spent years rebuilding my life. Now that she's growing older, I worry about how this will affect her. I hope she'll understand why I'm taking time off. I just wish there were more support systems for families dealing with domestic violence, especially during holidays like Christmas. But I won't let this one incident push me over the edge. I'll take a break, recharge, and come back stronger. I'll show everyone what I'm capable of. (she walked away)

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

He sat alone in his lab, the hum of machinery his only companion. The clock crept past midnight; another Saturday night spent under the cold glow of fluorescent lights. His colleagues had left hours ago, their laughter echoing down the empty hallways before disappearing into the night. He stared at his experiment, willing it to work, but even the science couldn't keep loneliness at bay tonight.

She was sitting by herself, reading a book outside the café where he stopped for coffee. If he'd walked past instead of through, they might have talked, maybe exchanged numbers, who knows, maybe she would've been interested in him too. What if she hadn't been so busy with her studies? Maybe she would have noticed him. But now she's just another face in the crowd, lost in her own thoughts, while he's stuck here alone, surrounded by machines that can never truly understand human emotions. He wondered what it would be like if he'd seen her again. Would she still think of him? Would she ever look up from her books and notice me? Or was it all just a fleeting moment, a chance encounter that slipped away? He felt the same emptiness as always, no one to share it with, no one to hear his stories. Just the endless cycle of work, sleep, repeat. It was the same story every day, the same isolation, the same pain. Nothing changed, nothing would change. He was trapped in this life, unable to escape. The only thing constant was his loneliness, and it seemed to grow heavier each passing day. He imagined himself telling her everything—his dreams, fears, hopes—and she listening with an open heart. Triggering Event: He found their wedding photo, tucked behind a cookbook in his cluttered kitchen cabinet. The image stared back at him, her smile still bright and carefree, his own face beaming with a love that now felt like a bitter joke. He ripped it in half, letting the pieces flutter to the floor. "I hope you're happy," he muttered, more spiteful than he intended.
Generated Assessment: He remembered how she had once told him that he wasn't the most romantic guy, but he'd never thought about whether that was really true until he saw the two of them holding hands in that stupid Disney commercial they'd been forced to watch for their anniversary. Now he wondered if anyone would have even noticed if he hadn't pointed out that her hand looked better in the frame than his. He chuckled to himself as he thought about how much better it would've looked if he'd been the one standing there instead.
